[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
PHASING OUT OF OLD GOODS VEHICLES


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Hwang Soo Jin -

    1. To ask the Minister for Communications if he will inform the House the manner in which it is proposed to phase out goods-carrying vehicles more than 15 years old and whether he will assure the House that in phasing out such vehicles sufficient notice will be given to individual owners so as to minimise hardships and to ensure adequate lorry services to users.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ong Teng Cheong.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong (Kim Keat): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Registry of Vehicles (ROV) records

Column: 192

show that there are about 9,500 goods vehicles which are over 15 years old. Of this figure, about 2,400 are over 26 years old, and another 1,300 between 22 and 26 years.

    As goods vehicles generate a large amount of economic activity, it would not be advisable to take them off the roads suddenly but to have them phased out gradually. Accordingly, the mechanically unfit or oldest vehicles will have to go off the roads first. To ensure that there is no disruption to the services provided by the goods vehicles, as well as to give the owners sufficient time to replace the scrapped vehicles, a grace period of six months to two years, depending on the mechanical condition of the over-aged vehicles, would be given. Under the phase out programme, the ROV will send notices to owners of over-aged vehicles, notifying them of the dates to bring their vehicles for mechanical inspection. These over-aged vehicles, if found mechanically unfit on inspection, would be given 14 days to rectify the faults.

Column: 193

If, after repairs are carried out, these vehicles pass the re-inspection, they would be given 12 months extension. Such extension would be renewable subject to satisfying the annual inspection up to 31st December, 1974, thus giving them a grace period up to two years. However, vehicles that fail the re-inspection after repairs would be given six months' notice to replace. The insurance company would be notified also by copy of letter to them.

    It should be stated that a large number of goods vehicles' owners have voluntarily, or at ROV's recommendation, scrapped their over-aged and unroadworthy vehicles ever since the White Paper on the Reorganisation of the Motor Transport Service of Singapore (Paper Command 21 of 1970) was published in July 1970. Up to September 1972 about 2,500 over-aged and unroadworthy goods vehicles had been scrapped and replaced by new vehicles.

    May I also take this opportunity to answer a question posed yesterday by an hon. Member as to how we were

Column: 194

going to prevent parents from having more children after allocating Housing and Development Board flats to them. The answer to the question is that priorities for the allocation of HDB flats will not only be for the application for the first flat but also for application for transfers to a bigger and better flat. In other words, if those who after having been allocated flats continue after 1st August, 1973, to have more children, then their application for transfers to bigger flats in the future will drop very low in priority. They should then not blame anyone other than themselves if' they and their bigger families had to remain in their smaller flats for a very long time.

Column: 194

PRESIDENT'S SPEECH

Debate on the Address
(Fourth Day)


2.55 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate' on Question [16th October, 1972],

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to: -

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mr Chai Chong Yii].

    Question again proposed.

Column: 195



    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion of thanks to the President, moved by the Member for Bukit Batok, and in this, I am categorically backed by the community leaders and people of Potong Pasir.

    Sir, too true the Government will have to discourage the creation of a more "cushioned" society in Singapore. Singaporeans will need to learn that rewards should be equated to hard work or personal performance. But, in areas where the people are willing to work hard - in the vegetable farms of Potong Pasir, for instance - there should be no curbs. Urban renewal is threatening to erase the lust for hard work these vegetable farmers possess. More than 1,500 people depend on these farms for a living, directly or indirectly. Here, on 120 hectares of rich land is grown, among other vegetables, nasturtium officinale or watercress. The alluvial soil of the Jalan Potong Pasir area permits the successful growth of this much cherished vegetable, which possesses medicinal value and is good for the health. It is said that the same vegetable from Cameron Highlands is flat to the palate. While preserving the essence of the vegetable by letting it continue growing in Potong Pasir, the Government would also preserve its policy -just returns for hard work. I say, Sir, let not the farmers be swallowed up by urban renewal. Let them continue sweating, toiling and doing what they love to do, until they are prepared to rest their aching bones in a Housing and Development Board flat or to repose in deserved peace in the bosom of the creator.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, that "nothing in life is for free" should be the axiom of every Singaporean. Many still feel this is balderdash. But, observe, even the air we breathe will cost much because we will need to spend large sums of money to keep it fresh. The Government

Column: 196

will have a task ahead to eliminate this cancer of air, water and noise pollution. The increased attention the Government is giving to questions about the environment is most welcome. It is hoped that the Environment Ministry will indicate priorities and act on them. The work of this Ministry will be important to the well-being of the community at large.

    For a start, my humble suggestions, Mr Speaker, Sir, are that the Environment Ministry:-

    (1) selects problem areas and either take action or make further inquiries;

    (2) publishes information regarding the environment that otherwise would not be available to the public;

    (3) establishes, where appropriate, international co-operation to preserve the environment.

    Action to control pollution is the responsibility of the Government, industry, trade unions and the general public. All must be made aware of this, and none should be allowed to shirk their responsibilities. Voluntary organisations could also play a valuable part in mobilising public opinion about pollution problems.

    Central to the pollution problem is the need to strike a balance between the benefits of economic growth and the technological development on which it depends, on the one hand, with the costs in terms of harm to the environment, on the other. The Government should institute a study of the costs of pollution as part of a wider action to provide an economic framework to aid decision-making about those economic and technological developments whose benefits are accompanied by some adverse effects on the environment.

    There are a number of forms, or causes, of pollution giving concern, and immediate action is necessary to deal with the most serious issues. Sea pollution, for instance, can be limited if

Column: 197

there is tight control on the dumping of noxious material; to limit noise pollution, there must be a general reduction in levels; for refuse disposal on land, action is needed to firmly control the disposal of toxic wastes; with fresh water pollution, ways and means will have to be devised to meet the increasing demand for water, and I am glad that in the Addendum to the President's address, the Ministry of the Environment indicates the using up of valuable land for new reservoirs.

    The Ministry of the Environment will need to go into the qualifications and training of those who control air, water and noise pollution. Constant vigilance of international development of improved techniques for monitoring pollution will have to be kept. There is a necessity also to have a continuing appraisal of pesticides. Close proximity with other bodies dealing with motor vehicle fumes, disposal of farm wastes, oil pollution of the sea and clean air, must be preserved. Complex problems .of pollution have to be tackled in a sensible and practical manner. Undoubtedly a correct balance between economic benefit and environmental cost is difficult to achieve, but this is an urgent problem that needs to be solved. It is especially important to take into account the costs and benefits to the general community, and in some instances the specific effects on workers, of the alternative ways of promoting economic and technological development.

    Granted, Mr Speaker, Sir, we must pay for what we want in life. But must some of the workers pay with their lives or mangled limbs! Occupational Health and Safety is a real problem in Singapore. It concerns the well-being of more than half a million people in their daily work. Finding the right answers does not seem possible, but I hope to make some contribution that will provide a reinvigorated, constructive and realistic step forward in an area where there is a crying need for a new approach. Many people are killed at work yearly

Column: 198

and many more injured and more than 100,000 man-days are lost annually because of industrial . accidents and diseases. Quite apart from human tragedy and suffering, the waste of resources is colossal. In Singapore today, there is little evidence to suggest that the situation is getting better. But there are signs suggesting a worsening of the situation. Many new and difficult problems will arise because of the use of potentially dangerous substances and materials. Some of these present direct risks to the public as well as the workers.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, can I humbly contribute the following suggestions which may alleviate the problems:

    (1) That a more comprehensive and stringent legislation, progressive in character and unified under a single Act, be introduced for the benefit of all the workers and also adequately protecting the interests of the public;

    (2) That the enforcement machinery for Health and Safety at work be revitalised into a better, keener, more streamlined and more dedicated body;

    (3) That Health and Safety organisations at work-places be set up, charged with the responsibility of continuously monitoring and controlling health and safety problems as they arise and as they change. For this to be successful, employers should be obliged to consult with their employees on Health and Safety measures;

    (4) That an education system be set up for everyone in industry to stimulate a sustained interest and involvement in Health and Safety at work;

    (5) That specialist training be given to safety officers, supervisors, technical staff (including engineers, chemists, plant designers, etc.), safety instructors, work study staff, specialist workers whose work involves special risks, workers' safety representatives and all members of joint safety committees;

    (6) That Health and Safety be organised as an integral function of management. Health and Safety must

Column: 199

be accepted as a policy from top to bottom of every undertaking, and this must be reflected in organisation and methods throughout the works; and

    (7) That there should be compulsory regular medical examination of workers at the expense of their employers to ensure fitness for employment. Apart from the wide range of jobs in which the safety of others is involved (transport drivers and crane drivers, for example) and where a medical examination might reveal at least the grosser causes for action, any person returning to work after a long bout of sickness, disabled persons, the chronic sick, pregnant women and older workers might well benefit by medical appraisal of their condition in relation to their work.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, certain sections of the Workmen's Compensation Act need to be reviewed to ensure that workers are fairly treated. For instance, in Singapore today, an injured workman cannot maintain a claim on his employer for workmen's compensation and at the same time pursue a claim for damages under Common Law. The same applies to the next-of-kin of workers killed at work. Workers or their relatives have to elect under which heading they would take their remedy, and the acceptance of compensation is a barrier to a damages claim. In other words, it is compensation or damages. Generally under Common Law, the quantum of compensation is higher presuming employers' negligence. Most workers and their relatives opt for workmen's compensation, because of this legislation, and due to the worker being unemployed or dead when the claim is made, because the families need the money. Other factors considered by the workers or their families are the protracted nature of a law suit, the costs and the uncertainty of the outcome, as proving employers' negligence is not a cut-and-dry affair.

    A possible amendment to enable workers to obtain a just compensation, especially when employers are negligent, is to allow workers to first accept

Column: 200

payment under the Workmen's Compensation Act and then if tort is successful later, the worker could reimburse the compensation paid under the Act.

    Undue delays in the payment of compensation cause workers and their families much hardship. The time taken in finalising workmen's compensation claims varies from case to case, depending on the nature of the accident and the extent of the injury. Before an assessment can be made, it is necessary to ensure that the claim is in order and substantiated by an authentic medical report. All the red tape is appreciated, but how do the workers and their families survive while all this is going on? Surely a satisfactory compromise can be worked out with either government or employers; this could be stipulated in the Act.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, a problem which presents a challenge to both sides of industry, management and workers alike is "occupational dermatitis", a condition arising out of one's work. It needs, however, to be emphasised that dermatitis is not confined to industry alone. Household and gardening duties are all a possible source of contraction of dermatitis. At one time it was being contended that the use of modern detergents and cleansers carried a distinct risk of dermatitis, though the manufacturers of such products could strongly dispute this. However, our consideration is industrial dermatitis and we have to recognise that this scourge is a particular feature of modern industry bringing with it not only much suffering and inconvenience for workers afflicted but also retarding the country's productive output. Dermatitis is most common in industrial processes where raw materials are handled. Chemicals, alkalies, de-greasing agents, coal-tar products, mineral oils and artificial adhesives cause dermatitis. Not only is it necessary to impress upon employers the need to adopt the most modern methods in order to combat dermatitis, but there is also an equal need for Government to include in the Second Schedule to the principal Act "Occupational Dermatitis" as a compensable disease.

Column: 201



    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is unjust to pay the industrious the same quantum as the indolent. But how do we get about correcting this injustice? The obvious answer is the introduction of a merit premium or a performance allowance. This additional allowance is determined by, the quantity and quality of the workers' products. This system would mean that over and above the basic wage, a worker can take home additional sums of money according to his daily performance at work. The introduction of such a system would ensure that those who work harder would be amply rewarded.

    Sir, maintaining and continuing the rapid pace of industrial and economic growth in Singapore for continued high growth rates is not an easy task. The willingness to work cannot be inculcated without the co-operation of both workers and entrepreneurs. The working relationship between entrepreneurs and labour many a time is aggravated by suspicion, false fears and self-destroying opposition. Until there is a harmonious and positive co-operation and unity of purpose in industrial life, struggles for higher productivity, increasing efforts and better standards of living can make little progress.

    A requirement for the right sort of leadership especially in management is visualised because this leadership determines the quality of human relations and morale in any enterprise.

    Continuously, entrepreneurs make attempts to motivate workers by monetary incentives only. This does not achieve the all-important goal of the realisation that workers are human beings and not economic digits. Workers want, most of all, to be a part of society, their opinions respected, and doing their lot in ensuring the success of the nation. They cannot and must not be treated as second-rate by management. They should always be treated as a part of the company in which they work in because the success or failure of the enterprise is largely dependent on them. There should be created a greater sense of participation among employees and job-satisfaction.

Column: 202



    If workers are made a part of the company on a co-operative basis, the incentive to work harder for the success of their enterprise will be ensured. This is evident in Japan. The communion of thought between management and, workers successfully implemented ultimately leads to a stable industrial relations climate, which is important socially as well as economically.

    In the tripartite association of Government, entrepreneurs and labour, Government has a responsibility to take a fundamental step forward to establish this co-operative relationship between entrepreneurs and labour. The changes envisaged would mean new obligations, on entrepreneurs as well as labour. New rights would be given to labour, and new powers and responsibilities to Government.

    Last but not least, Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to echo the sentiments of the Member for Telok Blangah by stressing that there is a dearth of concern over the aged and underprivileged. It is not their fault that they are old, deaf, blind, dumb, mentally handicapped or spastic. The Government must pledge a guaranteed share in our rising national prosperity for these less fortunate. Most certainly we are conscious of the many difficulties at present experienced by these people. I urge that immediate action be taken to provide more adequate and imaginative help for them.

3.15 p.m.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (River Valley): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to add my support to the motion by the hon. Member for Bukit Batok. The President's address contains many good, guidelines and policies which the Government will implement over the next five years. I feel that every citizen should assist the Government to achieve these objectives in the coming years.

    The important stress on quality is well accepted by all concerned, and we welcome the formation of the Ministry of the Environment for preserving and striving towards a better environment for Singapore. While it is accepted that this Ministry has an important function

Column: 203

to perform, we also have to recognise some of the difficulties that it will face with regard to staffing and the lack of many experienced personnel in implementing some of these policies. In our eagerness to preserve the environment, we must ensure that unnecessary hardship is not placed upon innocent people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the setting up of the Ministry of the Environment is being received with some mixed feelings by some members of the public. There is a fear by this hesitant group that the over-enthusiasm in the implementation of some of these policies without proper knowledge and study can cause extreme hardship to some industries, especially the local small industries.

    I would like to add that some local industries over the past year have been quite apprehensive of what the Government actually intends to do with regard to pollution control problems, as there is no clear-cut guideline on what should or should not be done. I would therefore like to suggest that the new Ministry of the Environment should issue some general guidelines so that the officers of this Ministry could implement the policy in the true spirit of the legislation rather than to the letter, for after all people who are earnest and sincere in wanting to help Government implement its policies should not be penalised. But, on the other hand, we must also have a mechanism, or machinery, to identify those who pay lip service and constantly flout the law for self-interest and benefits.

    I am sure that the concerned members of the public would like to know some clear-cut statements from this Ministry concerning the relevant implementations. Otherwise it can drive away a number of new industries which ironically the other Ministries may be trying very hard to promote. Moreover, some existing industries feel reluctant to expand as there is uncertainty regarding the enforcement of the environment laws.

    The introduction of legislation to fight pollution is obviously a step in the

Column: 204

right direction. However, there must be flexibility in its enforcement as antipollution equipment is very expensive and this may cause a strain on the finances of some small manufacturing firms.

    The next point I would like to comment, Sir, concerns the easing of manpower shortage. Singapore is presently facing an acute shortage of manpower, especially in the higher levels. These high-calibred and experienced personnel cannot be created overnight, but need to be nurtured over many years. One of the ways to help solve this problem is the relaxation of immigration policies. But this has its limitations, among the most obvious being the need for adjustment to a new environment, the lack of dedication and the danger of importing people of dubious talents. Perhaps a more realistic way to help solve and ease this problem immediately is the conservation and better utilisation of existing selected manpower. This can be done by allowing to reduce the annual leave with financial compensation.

    Sir, it is usually the experienced senior civil servants who are most needed on important jobs. Simultaneously, they are the same staff who are eligible for the most annual leave by virtue of their seniority and their length of service. Consequently, some senior staff have been accumulating their leave to an unhealthy level. Much discontent would result if some of their annual leave are forfeited. This conflicting state of affairs can be alleviated for the better by compensating for shortening leave, if required.

    In the public sector, senior staff are eligible for 33, or 39, or 42 days' annual leave a year, depending on seniority and length of service, in comparison with leave entitlement in the private sector of 14 or 21 days. In trying to equate the terms of service in the public sector to those in the private sector, this simple fact is often overlooked. Therefore, in the re-examination of service conditions as mentioned in the addendum to the President's Address

Column: 205

(Ministry of Finance) for senior civil servants, I would like to suggest that the reduction of annual leave for selected staff in exchange for financial compensation should be studied.

    The recent unsatisfactory situation as regards general maintenance of Far East Mansion in my constituency has brought home the point of another social problem in Singapore. I therefore feel that the House ought to re-examine the problem of the administration and maintenance of the common property and common area of flatted buildings. The statutory provision which governs the administration and maintenance of common areas of flatted buildings is the Land Titles (Strata) Act (Cap. 277) which came into force on the 15th of May, 1968. Part IV of this Act provides for the setting up of a corporate body called the "Management Corporation" for every flatted building. The Management Corporation is administered by a Council selected from and by the owners of flats in the flatted building. Section 19 of the Act sets Out the duties and obligations of the Management Corporation among which it is the duty of the Management Corporation to manage and properly maintain the common property and the common areas of the flatted building, and to keep the same in good and serviceable repair. Section 29 of the Act provides that if the Management Corporation is in default of its obligations under Section 19, then the Management Corporation and every member of its Council shall be liable to a fine not exceeding $500.

    To-date, many flatted buildings in Singapore have yet to set up effective Management Corporations. The main reason appears to be that it is rather idealistic and sometimes impracticable to expect flat owners to undertake the responsibility of initiating the formation of the Council. Perhaps a separate department for the implementation of Part IV of the Land Titles (Strata) Act should be established by the Government.

    The interim measures adopted so far are for the developer of the flatted building to undertake, prior to the

Column: 206

setting up of the Management Corporation, responsibility for the upkeep and maintenance of the common areas. The undertaking is incorporated usually in the Agreements for Sale and Purchase between each buyer of the flat and the developer. The developer's obligations here are, therefore, strictly contractual and the only remedy available to the owners of the flats in case of default of the developer is to institute a civil suit in court. This usually takes a long time, as we all know. This is clearly an unsatisfactory state of affairs, as in the case of Far East Mansions for instance. I feel that the public have been inconvenienced to a great extent and measures ought to be taken by the Government to rectify the position.

    I would suggest that the statutory provisions of a Management Corporation be made to apply to developers so that any default of these statutory obligations to manage and keep in a state of good repair the common property and the common areas of the flatted building will result in the developer liable to a fine in the court. This calls for an amendment to the Land Titles (Strata) Act, and I feel that this may act as a deterrent to the housing developer who, very often after the erection and disposal of the flatted building to the members of the public, neglect to keep the common areas in a state of good repair and condition.

    The last point I would like to touch on, Sir, is our aims to create more satisfying and better paid jobs in Singapore. In this area, there is much to be done in upgrading the skills of our workers, although the Ministry of Education and the tertiary institutions have' been expanded. This alone is insufficient, as the institutions can do no more than provide basic training. In order to achieve higher technology and better skills to make Singapore into a service centre, there is a need to have better cooperation and understanding between those who work in the Government departments and those in the private sector. Therefore, I would like to suggest that a more effective consultative machinery be established.

Column: 207



3.26 p.m.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui): Mr Speaker, Sir, in supporting the motion moved by the hon. Member for Bukit Batok, thanking the President for his thought-provoking Address, I take the opportunity to elaborate on some of the points mentioned concerning the Ministry of Labour.

    As indicated in the Addendum to the Address, we will allow industries or enterprises with high technology or higher skill content, and the prospects of more sophisticated manufacture, to recruit labour on work permits liberally. This is to ensure that the growth of our industries will not be hampered through lack of manpower. The Government is now working on a new scheme which will enable work permits to be issued readily and more expeditiously to what we consider to be "priority industries". A list of such industries will be drawn up and the scheme will be carefully implemented through greater co-operation and co-ordination between the Economic Development Board and the Labour Ministry. We will also inform employers of the scheme so as to facilitate them in the recruitment of foreign workers. In other words, everything possible will be done to ensure that our industries as well as those to be set up will have the requisite number of workers with the right type of qualities needed by them. Would-be investors, therefore, need not have unnecessary fears about difficulties in recruitment.

    In the long run, however, we should not depend too much upon the immigrant workers to meet our labour requirements. More important, we must train and upgrade the skills of our own workers not only to meet the needs of our industrialisation programme but also to raise their standard of living through increased efficiency and productivity, and hence higher wages. This task calls for the joint effort of Government, the employers and the trade unions. The Government will do its

Column: 208

part mainly through the Industrial Training Board to be set up soon. The Board will undertake and co-ordinate all aspects of industrial training, including apprenticeship schemes as well as-on-the-job and off-the-job training. It, will also regulate and control such training schemes to ensure that the training given is of a high standard and relevant to the needs of our industries. In this way, a growing pool of technically skilled personnel will be made available to effectively meet the demands of an increasingly industrialised economy.

    To keep abreast with the changing times, it is necessary for our employers to adopt modern and scientific management techniques.
